repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Adds support for `hi Foo cterm=altfont`

Renders altfont in `tui.c` by using `SGR 11`, select first alternative font.

Still TODO:
 - [ ] Talk to terminfo library maintainer (Thomas Dickey) about allocating an official mode name for it
 - [ ] Talk to unibilium (@mauke) about supporting it
 - [x] Write docs
 - [ ] Tests?
 - [ ] Extract altfont knowledge from `:terminal` so it highlights correctly though that too

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -149,6 +149,8 @@ The following new APIs or features were added.
   deterministic, and a `LUA_GEN_PRG` build parameter has been introduced to
   allow for a workaround for some remaining reproducibility problems.
 
+• |:highlight| now supports an additional attribute 'altfont'.

comment_regular_data.body: @bfredl The CI failures are warnings that because the highlight flags now span the full 16 bits they no longer fit nicely in an `int16_t` for serialisation purposes. I don't know whether to expand the field to `int32_t` (which seems a waste of the other 15 bits), or to see if the existing flags can be squashed down a little bit. Happy to take suggestions either way.
Are you sure this attribute isn't relevant to GUIs (or, more importantly, terminals supporting `termguicolors`) as well?

> Are you sure this attribute isn't relevant to GUIs (or, more importantly, terminals supporting `termguicolors`) as well?

Oh it quite possibly is. Or at least, if the GUI had a way to e.g. `set guialtfont=...` alongside the regular font then you could use the attribute to swap between them, yes.
I just want to make sure that `gui=altfont` is also supported by your PR (since the description implies you've only implemented `cterm=altfont`).

In principle the underlines _could_ be squashed down under the assumption that you only can enable one of them. i e instead of five bits for five underlines there would just be three bits (covering "off" and up to 7 styles of underlines)
but as TUI _litterally is_ another GUI at this point, it must be supported by GUI:s to be supported at all.

I've fixed up all the tests I could easily manage, but there's still one failing.

```
FAILED   test/functional/legacy/syn_attr_spec.lua @ 10: synIDattr() works
test/functional/legacy/syn_attr_spec.lua:44: Expected objects to be the same.
Passed in:
(string) '1'
Expected:
(string) ''
```

Reading the source of that test it isn't obvious to me what it's trying to do, nor why my change causes it to fail. Perhaps someone else will have more luck?

> I've fixed up all the tests I could easily manage, but there's still one failing.
> 
> ```
> FAILED   test/functional/legacy/syn_attr_spec.lua @ 10: synIDattr() works
> test/functional/legacy/syn_attr_spec.lua:44: Expected objects to be the same.
> Passed in:
> (string) '1'
> Expected:
> (string) ''
> ```
> 
> Reading the source of that test it isn't obvious to me what it's trying to do, nor why my change causes it to fail. Perhaps someone else will have more luck?

With this PR, `synIDattr()` is returning 1 for any underline highlight attribute for a highlight group that has an underline highlight attribute.

Right. Tests appear to be passing. I believe I've written docs.
I've talked to Thomas Dickey and @mauke but I'm not sure what response we might get, or whether we ought to wait for that. We can handle that later perhaps.

Anything else missing on this or does it look good to un-draft it?
@leonerd looks good to undraft. let get this merged soon and we can adjust later if one of those choose to respond, later :]
Undrafted, and the linter is upset about my commit messages :(

I had a guess at what might appease the commit-message linter. Then I add to add some text to `news.txt`, and now the tests are upset with what I wrote there. :(

Any advice anyone?

Excellent. And already I'm able to use it in fixed-width "code" tags in POD
![nvim-altfont](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/350941/214320995-27ec9903-a8ca-4ca1-959e-cc048020f6b9.png)

I like the possibilities of this :) beautiful work!

I don't quite remember if this was ever in the standard, I feel like I remember technically the standard did have ways to switch to alternative fonts (up to 10?). But hardly any emulator supports it, right? I can't find any mention of it in `alacritty` or `kitty`. Which emulator are using to be able to take advantage of this?
I created an issue about this on the kitty repo a long time ago: kovidgoyal/kitty#5268 and it was not received well.

haha funny that you mention this :) The alacritty team is similarly negative when it comes to fancy requests like this. But there must be at least one good emulator out there, the original author of this didn't do it just for fun, right?

However, reading a bit thru https://github.com/kovidgoyal/kitty/issues/5268 they say they dont want to deal with different fonts and sizing issues. Yet it's already possible to define different fonts for normal, italic, bold, and bold+italic, which seems to be the exact same complexity. People often use that to have some kind of alternative fonts.

> Which emulator are using to be able to take advantage of this?

I'm using pangoterm, which I wrote. It handles this just fine. It's also built on the same `libvterm` that neovim itself uses.

Here's a screenshot of pangoterm running nvim, showing some documentation in POD format.
![pangoterm-nvim-altfont](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/350941/57cc889a-439c-46de-8ae1-d2469b9e9d6e)

repo.name: neovim

title: Support `altfont` as a term rendering attribute
